content.description: Climb a short crack to a thin, sloping mantel, followed by face climbing diagonally up and left.
content.protection: None. Must be top-roped from a small tree at the top after leading Flake of Fire or by scrambling along the top of the cliff from the double-bolt anchor on the left side of the main face.
content.location: Starts at a short vertical crack just left of Flake of Fire, near the right end of the main face.

content.description: Climb a steep face with loose bucket holds to a slab with thin holds, finishing on scary, loose blocks at the top.
content.protection: None. Must be top-roped from a small tree at the top after leading Flake of Fire or by scrambling along the top of the cliff from the double-bolt anchor on the left side of the main face.
content.location: Starts on a steep face to the right of the obvious hand crack (Old Time Revival) and left of Zinfandel.

content.description: The easiest climb on the crag. Step up on a large vertical flake at the base and climb up a vague crack and face. The easiest moves are to the right of the bolts. VARIATION: Climbing the face within a foot or two left of the bolts is 5.9.
content.protection: Three bolts to a double-bolt anchor. Can also be led as a trad climb with several options for 0.5" to 1.25" nuts and cams.
content.location: Near the left end of the cliff. Starts from a large vertical flake at the base just left of the overhanging "bell."

content.description: Climb the obvious hand crack, which is vertical for 10 feet and then becomes lower angle with a couple of steep bulges in the middle and at the top. The upper part is surprisingly sustained. A bit dirty.
content.location: Obvious hand crack in the middle of the crag.

climbs.name: Lure of Lucre
climbs.fa: Unknown  (bolted and led by Floyd Hayes, November 2007)

content.description: Relatively clean, long and sustained, this is the best climb at the crag. Surmount a short overhang just right of the overhanging "bell," mantel onto a small pillar, then climb thin face to a double-bolt anchor. The climb is hardest and most sustained if you climb straight up through the bolts, easier if you move left. Above the third bolt either: (1) climb straight up above the last bolt, which is a bit runout (final move is 5.10a); (2) place a small nut or cam in a groove to protect the final move; or (3) move left and clip the last bolt on Once Upon a Climb for an easier 5.6 finish.
content.protection: Three or four bolts plus optional nut or cam.
content.location: Left of the obvious large hand crack (Old Time Revival). Starts just right of the overhanging "bell" where a bolt is placed just left of a short vertical crack.

climbs.name: Liberty Bell
climbs.fa: Unknown  (bolted and led by Floyd Hayes, December 2007)

content.description: Essentially a boulder problem: surmount the left side of the overhanging "bell" (crack to the left is off route) and then climb up the "liberty crack" to the top, finishing on either Once Upon a Climb to the left or Lure of Lucre to the right.
content.protection: 1 bolt just above the crux overhang; 1 or 2 bolts above depending on which option is used to finish the climb. Another option above the crack is placing 0.75-1.25" nuts or cams in the vague crack.
content.location: Starts on the left side of the overhanging "bell" just right of Once Upon a Climb and left of the obvious hand crack (Old Time Revival).

climbs.name: Handburger
climbs.fa: Unknown (bolted and led by Floyd Hayes, May 2008)

content.description: Climb short, thin hand cracks straight up, then diagonally up and left to the arete, then climb the face (protected by a bolt) up and right to a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Several small to medium cams plus 1 spinning bolt (sorry it didn't go int well) that should hold a short fall.
content.location: At the left edge of the main face, starting at the first crack left of Once Upon a Climb.

content.description: Climb up a short, somewhat loose face, lieback left underneath and then up the left edge of a large flake, and finish on an offwidth crack. The climbing is good but none of the anchor options are appealing.
content.protection: Three bolts plus a large cam (2-3") for the offwidth crack. There is a double-bolt anchor with chains on the outer edge of the block, but it looks like weighting it could pull off the block, which would probably be fatal. Instead continue upward and belay off one of several small trees at the top of the crag. It's best to belay your partner up and then rappel down off of a tree.
content.location: On the right side of the main face of the crag, just left of where the rock becomes broken up.

content.description: Climb the face a few feet left of the obvious hand crack (Old Time Revival).
content.location: Starts just left of the obvious hand crack (Old Time Revival).
